title: Pastrnak scores twice, hits 400-goal milestone as Bruins beat Maple Leafs
author: The Associated Press
bullets: David Pastrnak scores two goals, including his 400th career goal, leading the Bruins to a 5-3 victory over the Maple Leafs.
Jeremy Swayman made 30 saves for Boston, while Pavel Zacha, Hampus Lindholm, and Alex Steeves added goals in the win.
Toronto's Auston Matthews leaves with a lower-body injury and Anthony Stolarz was replaced due to an upper-body injury.

title: Jeff Passan maps out ‘perfect’ offseason move for the Red Sox
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Red Sox GM Craig Breslow prioritizes adding a top-tier pitcher to support Garrett Crochet in the rotation.
MLB insider Jeff Passan suggests Red Sox should pursue Twins' pitcher Joe Ryan in a trade.
Joe Ryan had a strong 2025 season with a 3.42 ERA and 194 strikeouts over 171 innings.

title: Patriots players got a surprise blue-collared gift from Mike Vrabel
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Mike Vrabel gifted the Patriots blue-collared shirts inspired by an idea from his time with the Browns.
Vrabel did not elaborate on the shirts' meaning, but presents them as motivational attire for the team.
The Patriots are on a seven-game win streak ahead of their divisional matchup against the 2-7 Jets.

title: ‘Ride and Walk for Your Life’ pedals toward safer streets, will push for reform
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: 'Ride and Walk for Your Life Boston' events include a memorial bike ride, walk, and State House rally for safer streets.
Events aim to support two Massachusetts bills on traffic law enforcement and truck safety to reduce road fatalities.
Organizers emphasize the coalition's role in advocating for safer infrastructure and honoring road traffic victims.

title: Tips for getting stubborn bird droppings off of an SUV
author: John Paul
bullets: AAA's Car Doctor advises using warm water and dish detergent with a microfiber cloth to soften stubborn bird droppings.
A handheld steamer, like the one from WORX products, can help remove tough bird droppings from a vehicle.
Consult a professional car detailer if home solutions fail to prevent potential paint damage from bird droppings.

title: Patriots have a new secret weapon on offense in 335-pound defensive tackle
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Khyiris Tonga, a 335-pound defensive tackle, is used as a two-way player for the New England Patriots.
Tonga is praised for his ability to clear paths as a fullback and contribute on special teams.
Mike Vrabel sees Tonga as a versatile asset, playing on three phases of the game for the Patriots.

title: What Joe Thornton said about the Bruins during his Hall of Fame induction speech
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Joe Thornton thanked Boston and Bruins alumni during his Hockey Hall of Fame induction speech.
Thornton, drafted by the Bruins in 1997, scored 454 points in 532 games with the team.
Thornton highlighted mentorship from Bruins alumni like Johnny Bucyk during his early NHL years.

title: Several key Patriots players still limited in latest injury report
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Kayshon Boutte and Rhamondre Stevenson remain limited in practice due to hamstring and toe injuries, respectively.
Austin Hooper and Joshua Farmer did not participate in practice owing to concussion and ankle injuries.
TreVeyon Henderson and several others returned as full participants, easing some injury concerns before facing the Jets.

title: Man, ‘significant’ number of birds and snakes killed in Methuen house fire, department says
author: Sana Muneer
bullets: A house fire in Methuen killed a man and many birds and snakes early Tuesday morning, officials said.
The fire occurred at 38 Atkinson St. around 2:20 a.m. and resulted in catastrophic damage, the fire department reported.
Three people escaped the fire; the cause is under investigation by Methuen fire, police, and state fire officials.

title: What readers say Boston Mayor Michelle Wu should prioritize in her next term
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Housing affordability and public safety are the top concerns for Boston Mayor Michelle Wu's second term, readers say.
A Boston.com poll showed 49% of respondents prioritized housing and safety, with 80 people participating.
Residents urge policy changes such as zoning adjustments and increased rent assistance to address housing challenges.
